[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_SEEK_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Cardinality Explosion] Can an attacker create unlimited column families with arbitrary cf_name values to cause unbounded metric cardinality explosion, exhausting validator memory and causing node crashes? [File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_SEEK_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Label Injection] Does the 'tag' label on line 17 accept unsanitized input that could allow attackers to inject arbitrary label values (seek_to_first, seek_to_last, seek, seek_for_prev), creating metric pollution and storage exhaustion? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_SEEK_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Bucket Configuration DoS] The exponential_buckets on line 18 starts at 1e-6 with factor 2.0 and count 22 - can an attacker exploit bucket boundary edge cases to cause histogram observation failures or memory allocation spikes during metric recording? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_SEEK_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Timing Side Channel] Does exposing seek latency metrics with microsecond precision (1e-6 start) create timing side channels that reveal state tree structure or access patterns, allowing attackers to infer private transaction data? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_SEEK_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Resource Exhaustion] With 22 exponential buckets and potentially unlimited cf_name/tag combinations, can sustained metric recording exhaust thread-local memory causing validator slowdowns or crashes during high-throughput periods? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_SEEK_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Integer Overflow] Can the exponential bucket calculation (1e-6 * 2^22) overflow float64 boundaries causing incorrect histogram observations that corrupt performance monitoring and hide attack patterns? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_SEEK_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Thread-Local Flush Attack] Since this uses make_thread_local_histogram_vec, can attackers trigger operations across many threads simultaneously to cause metric flush storms (1-second intervals) that degrade consensus performance? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_SEEK_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Observability Blind Spot] If seek operations fail before metrics are recorded, can attackers exploit this to perform unobservable state tree manipulation that bypasses monitoring and alerting systems? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_ITER_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Cardinality Attack] Does the cf_name label on line 29 allow unbounded column family creation that multiplies with 22 histogram buckets to exhaust Prometheus storage and cause monitoring system failures? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_ITER_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Latency Manipulation] Can Byzantine validators deliberately slow down iterator operations to skew this metric, hiding their poor performance while degrading network-wide state synchronization? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_ITER_LATENCY_SECONDS] [State Inference] Does exposing iterator latency patterns allow attackers to infer Jellyfish Merkle Tree depth and structure, enabling targeted denial-of-service attacks on specific state paths? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_ITER_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Memory Leak via Histograms] With exponential buckets (1e-6, 2.0, 22) on line 30, can long-running iterators cause histogram bucket memory to accumulate without proper cleanup, leading to validator memory exhaustion over time? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_ITER_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Race Condition] Can concurrent iterator operations from multiple threads cause RefCell borrow panics in the thread_local storage when recording metrics, crashing validator nodes during high load? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_ITER_BYTES] [No Bucket Configuration] This histogram on line 35 has no exponential_buckets parameter - does it use unbounded default buckets that could cause memory exhaustion when recording large iteration sizes during state synchronization? [File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_ITER_BYTES] [Size Overflow] Can attackers trigger iterator operations that return sizes exceeding f64 max value, causing metric observation failures that hide massive data exfiltration attempts? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_ITER_BYTES] [Resource Monitoring Bypass] If iteration byte metrics aren't recorded for failed operations, can attackers perform resource-intensive partial iterations that bypass monitoring thresholds and exhaust storage I/O? [File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_ITER_BYTES] [Privacy Leak] Does exposing exact iteration byte sizes allow attackers to fingerprint specific accounts or smart contracts by observing state access patterns, violating transaction privacy? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_GET_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Timing Attack] The 1-microsecond precision (1e-6) on line 53 with 22 exponential buckets - can attackers use high-resolution get latency observations to perform timing attacks that reveal cryptographic key material during signature verification? [File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_GET_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Cache Timing Side Channel] Can Byzantine validators analyze get operation latency distributions to infer RocksDB cache hit/miss patterns, learning which state keys are hot and targeting cache eviction attacks? [File: aptos-core/storage/schemadb/src/metrics.rs] [Metric: APTOS_SCHEMADB_GET_LATENCY_SECONDS] [Thread Exhaustion] With thread-local histograms, can attackers spawn unlimited threads that each allocate histogram memory for all cf_name combinations, exhausting validator memory through thread proliferation?
